title: Hour heroes! Smartwatches that don't make you like you have an electronic tag on your wrists
text:
Fossil Android Wear

fossil.com/uk, £279

The truly sad thing about smartwatches is that the one thing that you want most of all is that it doesn’t actually look like a smartwatch.

I always feel a faint pang of shame whenever my square fitness watch catches on my shirt sleeve and people notice it – or worse, I get a co-conspiratorial look from someone else wearing an Apple Watch.

Fossil’s Android Wear watches take the bold design decision of not looking like an electronic tag on your wrist, with proper, circular faces and metal rims

I always want to yell: ‘I just use it to count my footsteps, so I can lose a few pounds, I’m not a nerd like you.’

Hence the appeal of Fossil’s Android Wear watches, which take the bold design decision of not looking like an electronic tag on your wrist, with proper, circular faces and metal rims.

In most lighting conditions, you will be spared the natural shame and humiliation that comes from wearing a smartwatch.

Fossil’s new fifth-generation watches (the Julianna and Carlyle) add heart-rate functions and GPS for running, and look pretty decent, too – although if the ‘Julianna’ is meant to be worn by women, they need pretty mighty wrists to carry it off, as it clocks in at 44mm.

Fitbit-style functions come courtesy of Google’s free Fit app (although you can pair with others such as Strava on either Android or iPhone).

These Fossil watches are about the best Android Wear watches out there, and they work well (you swipe up, sideways and down to open alerts, see your calendar or see fitness data). But there’s a faint sense Android Wear has been left to wither on the vine – and these feel slightly dated, even at a lower price than Apple Watch.
